I have had some anger and depression issues myself and it is hard to deal with other problems which creep up.  They really test our patience (problems and children, LOL) so I can understand why you would want to confide in the nurse about all of this.  My heart goes out to you, especially facing the loss of your SO while at the same time dealing with all of this.  I do not have advice because I am new to this journey as well and don't even know if I'll be facing chemo like you, but please know that my prayers are with you and your precious daughter. Nancy
Posts.Title: relationship will not survive timerdog alamik

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2011 10:22AM BioAdoptMom3 wrote: You seem very concerned about the fact that you have to see a surgeon before you have your biopsy.  I was too at first, until I learned that my health insurance wouldn't allow a biopsy until I had a referral from a surgeon.  That honestly MAY be the only reason they want you to see one.  As for the biopsy vs. MRI, the biopsy is the only thing that can tell you 100% whether or not you have cancer or something else.  To possibly help relieve your mind a bit, most radiologists are extremely good about reading mammograms and ultrasounds.  Mine actually used the words probable cancer as did the ultrasound tech and in my case they were right.  I have had four other previous biopsies and in every single one of those the radiologists and techs said either they weren't sure, calcifications, adenomas, etc., words like that.  All of those were benign.  Your chances of this turning out to be benign are actually greater than 80%!  So, the odds are definitely in your favor.  Believe me, I know this is a scary time for you, but you are doing all the right things to stay on top of this. Get your biopsy and you will know exactly what you are dealing with.  Just try to keep in mind that most likely it is not cancer.  You are in my prayers. Nancy

Posts.Title: Very TMI question BioAdoptMom3 BioAdoptMom3

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2011 03:53AM BioAdoptMom3 wrote: I have had four diagnostic mammograms with ultrasound, three which resulted in biopsies.  Of those three biopsies, only the most recent one was found to be cancerous.  Let me give you some info to help relieve your mind a bit.  For the first two the radiologists told me that though it looked concerning, it still was most likely benign, what you heard too, and it was!  For this past one, both the radiologist who read the ultrasound and the one who performed the biopsy told me they were very concerned, that it looked typical of a malignant mass.  My two non-malignant masses were BIRAD4 and my most recent was a BIRAD5.  I am fairly new to this, but I believe that a BIRAD4 score is still more likely to be benign than malignant.  Let us know and in the meantime, know that we are here for you.  This is a great group of supportive women! Nancy
Posts.Title: newbie with a few questions jenvandy SarahsMom

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2011 12:12AM BioAdoptMom3 wrote: I am sorry you are having to bear the agony of waiting to know the results of your biopsy.  The waiting is absolutely horrible!  The odds are definitely in your favor though, even more so because of your age!  I am 52, have been called back 5 times and had 4 biopsies.  In all of the biopsies except for the last one the radiologist always said he was pretty sure it wasn't anything to worry about, but needed to be checked out.  In the last one he indicated that it looked very suspicious and that one was indeed cancer.  It was a birads 5 going in.  I have found that radiologists do not generally try to ease your mind about the possibility of cancer unless they are at least fairly certain that it's not.  Let us know what you hear, but the odds are in your favor for sure! Nancy

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2011 02:01PM BioAdoptMom3 wrote: GabbyCal, based on what I have been told recently and read, the chemo and hormone therapy decreases the chances of recurrance elsewhere in the body, while the surgery and radiation (for someone who had a lumpectomy) decreases the chances of cancer recurring in the breast.  Be prepared for any suggestion from your onco though.  I had a oncotype of 19 with a distant recurrance rate of 12% and my MO definitely wants me to do chemo.  I start this Friday.  You having a grade 1 tumor (mine was a 3) may make a big difference though.  Just want you to be prepared for his/her POSSIBLE suggestion of chemo.  ((((HUGS)))), prayers and good luck to you! Nancy

Posts.Title: Breast Cancer But Type Unknown? lifelover lifelover

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2011 11:30PM BioAdoptMom3 wrote: I am not staged yet and haven't even had my lumpectomy or started treatment and I too am feeling angry and depressed a lot of the time, even though the surgeon estimates that I am at a stage 1 or early 2 (pathology is not all back yet) and the outlook is of course very good.  I am not sure its because of the prognosis, or if people just don't know what else to say, but I am sick of hearing that I am strong, to stay strong or to be positive!  NO, I am NOT strong!  These people do not see me when my anger gets the best of me at home.  They didn't see me last Sunday morning in church when I got angry over something very minor that normally wouldn't have bothered me at all under different circumstances. They don't know how sad I feel because I had to cancel directing my children's chorus this semester because of all the radiation treatments and other medical appointments or how worried I am about how my children and my husband feel about all of this.  I am a newbie at all of this obviously, but to me your feelings sound very normal.  We are dealing with something very serious and something that turns our lives upside down no matter how positive or negative the prognosis may be!  (((((HUGS))))) to you and lots prayers! Nancy

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2010 01:20AM BioAdoptMom3 wrote: You may be required to meet with the surgeon for insurance reasons.  The appointment to get results is probably routine because whether your mass is benign or malignant, it is probably their policy to not give results over the phone.  It is also a time to discuss surgery or other options once you have your results.  I had to meet with a surgeon too, but I had to meet today, before my biopsy has even been scheduled.  That one was a requirement by my insurance company.  Good luck to you!

Posts.Title: Chemo May 2011 Cyborg

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2011 01:18PM BioAdoptMom3 wrote: Had my first treatment yesterday and overall it went well.  It took about five hours (T/C).  The infused steroids kept me awake until about 2 AM, but I slept fine after that, and had me eating everything in sight from about 9 PM!  Big mistake though was that I ate a piece of pepperoni pizza DS and his GF had delivered last night, about 11.  I am dealing with incredible heartburn and stomach pains today, but hopefully with the Milk of Magnesia tablets I've been taking, and th Tums, I'll get through that SOON.  Waited a little too long to take my Compazine last night as I did get somewhat nauseaous before going to sleep, but that's gone today thankfully and I am on top of it, every 6 hours today. Good luck to all the rest of you who are starting soon, or continuing with your current or new treatments!  We're all in this together and you are all on my prayer list.  Nancy
Posts.Title: Chemo May 2011 Cyborg

Posts.Content: May 5, 2011 02:48PM BioAdoptMom3 wrote: Welcome to all our newcomers since I was last here a few days ago.  It does help a lot to read about what others are experiencing and it sure helps me to not feel so alone!  I hadn't noticed anyone mentioning restless legs as part of your side effects.  I have never had it until the other night so I am pretty sure its either chemo or Neulasta related.  It kept me awake from like 1 AM till 4:30 AM so I called the onco who prescribed something called Klonopin, which is an anti-seizure med.  Has anyone been on that before?  I am only to take it as needed and its only 1 mg., but the side effects, most psychiatric, sound so scary.  As miserable as I was the other night I'm not so sure if I have the problem again I'll even take the medicine.  Maybe its such a low dose I won't have to worry about it. My bone aches from Neulasta started today but thankfully nothing that Tylenol can't control.  Its mostly affecting my lower back and legs. What tastes good to you guys?  I have having a hard time finding anything other than fruit smoothies and ice-cream, that tastes good to me.  (((((HUGS))))) to all! Nancy

Posts.Title: Chemo May 2011 Cyborg

Posts.Content: May 2, 2011 12:56PM BioAdoptMom3 wrote: Wow, seems like we all have those same feelings and fears and I don't think its vain at all to be so upset about hair loss.  It's a major part of our identity. I started my T/C on Friday and thankfully no nausea at all.  I faithfully took the Compazine every six hours until this morning and since getting the Neulasta yesterday have been faithfully taking Motrin every 8 hours (well, I started that last night).  So far the worst side effect of this whole thing has been the exhaustion.  My energy level between yesterday morning and this morning was ZERO!  With the exception of some bathroom and water breaks I pretty much slept from 9 AM Sunday through 11 AM today!  I am feeling more energetic today though and even though I have had some aching hips from what I assume is the Neulasta, its been totally controlled with the Motrin.  I wish all of you newly starting chemo buddies the best!  We can get through this together! Nancy
